Such thinking frequently occurs when contact
with the target population is sporadic, be¬
cause the distances which separate staff from
the population are too great, or because of
poor utilization of staff.
Each year, countless numbers of rural poor
people do die, because there is no way for them
to communicate their needs to even the nearest
town. This is a sobering reality which we must
face up to.
These kinds of communication needs are central
to the concerns of this document.
In thinking about an 0E0 "national" capability,
we must squarely face up to some realities:
1) The cost for one agency's "creating"
a unilateral capability in mass com¬
munications is prohibitive, even
allowing the possibility of open,
unallocated channels being available
in either radio or television.
